node.title: How to Find Common Ground With Your Most Problematic Family Members
node.description: To survive a dinner table disagreement with the people you love this Thanksgiving, donâ€™t call it a debate, Dylan Marron argues.
node.content: ["It\u2019s holiday time again, and this year feels different. Unlike the shelter-in-place aesthetic of 2020\u2019s holiday celebrations, many people are now vaccinated and hoping to take part in the sort of family and friend events that are more reminiscent of the prepandemic time. With that warmth and community, we all may find ourselves in another seasonal tradition: getting into an argument with people over the dinner table.", "[You can listen to this episode of \u201cThe Argument\u201d on Apple, Spotify or Google or wherever you get your podcasts.]", "Maybe it\u2019s a longstanding rivalry with a cousin, or a nosy aunt asking about your biological clock \u2014 or perhaps the uniquely 2020-2021 disagreements over masking, vaxxing and who actually won the election. Whatever your flavor of argument, host Jane Coaston and special guest Dylan Marron are here to help. Gleaning tips and advice from Dylan\u2019s podcast and forthcoming book of the same name, \u201cConversations With People Who Hate Me,\u201d Jane and Dylan lay out how to engage empathetically with the people who disagree with you, and how to avoid classic pitfalls that keep the discussion from being productive.", "(A full transcript of the episode will be available midday on the Times website.)"]
